item.title: Writing Science or Rewriting Reality?
item.description:
Introduction

“What if we wrote backwards? Not from Introduction to findings, but from findings back to the Introduction.”

IMRaD‚ÄîIntroduction, Methods, Results, and Discussion‚Äî functions as an editorial public good: it standardizes manuscripts, facilitates peer review, and enables cross-article comparisons.
Moreover, starting with the scientific problem matters: formulating it well is equivalent to having already solved half of it (1).

This post does not propose abandoning IMRaD, but rather distinguishing between two complementary orders:

  • Publication order (IMRaD): useful for evaluation and information retrieval
  • Writing order (guided by findings): useful for aligning the narrative with what we actually learned and separating confirmatory from exploratory analyses (2,3).

In practice: first draft the key Results (estimates, confidence intervals, relevance), then the Discussion (plausibility, biases, sensitivity), followed by fully transparent Methods (clearly stating what was pre-specified, what changed, and why), and finally a concise, precise Introduction that frames the actual research question or hypothesis truly aligned with the results.
The final manuscript still adheres to the IMRaD format.

When to Use It‚Äîand When Not To

Recommended for: observational studies, secondary analyses, unexpected discoveries, and applied data science where iteration is inevitable.

Use caution / Not recommended for: Registered Reports, confirmatory trials with pre-specified statistical analysis plans (SAPs) (CONSORT), and systematic reviews with pre-registered protocols (PRISMA).
In these cases, maintain the primacy of the original plan and explicitly label any exploratory components as such (4,5).

Critical Objections (and Evidence-Based Responses)

‚ÄúThis encourages HARKing.‚Äù

Response: quite the opposite‚Äîif explicit labeling and open materials are required.
HARKing involves concealment; here we demand clear differentiation between confirmatory and exploratory analyses and full documentation of any changes (6‚Äì8).

‚ÄúThe Introduction loses its purpose.‚Äù

Response: it actually becomes stronger.
It frames the real problem illuminated by the evidence, without forcing a fictitious chronological narrative. The ICMJE promotes IMRaD for clarity‚Äînot for rewriting history (9).

‚ÄúEditors require strict IMRaD compliance.‚Äù

Response: we preserve it.
Only the writing workflow changes, not the macrostructure. Moreover, TOP Guidelines and open practices enhance editorial trust (10).

‚ÄúUnexpected results are overvalued.‚Äù

Response: demand sensitivity analyses, negative controls, replication, and avoid fetishizing p < 0.05.

Transparency Checklist

Element Confirmatory Exploratory
Pre-specification Linked protocol/SAP Not pre-specified (with justification)
Results Labeled as pre-specified Labeled as post hoc
Analyses Conducted per plan Limited, with sensitivity analyses
Open resources Data/code/notebook shared Code and decision criteria documented

Conclusion

IMRaD structures and enables comparability across scientific articles.
Integrating a findings-driven writing approach offers a moderate, practical way to gain honesty, utility, and traceability‚Äîwithout sacrificing methodological rigor or editorial clarity.
In certain contexts‚Äîespecially exploratory ones‚Äîit can be the difference between a narrative faithful to discovery and a fictitious chronology.

item.title: Tutorial: An√°lisis de Fortificaci√≥n de Alimentos con HCES y R
item.description:
En este tutorial, aprender√°s a usar datos de Encuestas de Consumo y Gasto en Hogares (HCES) , Tablas de Composici√≥n de Alimentos (FCT) y herramientas de R (tidyverse, gtsummary, ggstatsplot) para evaluar la adecuaci√≥n nutricional y modelar escenarios de fortificaci√≥n. Los conceptos se explican desde cero, con ejemplos reproducibles.

Paso 1: Preparaci√≥n de datos HCES

Concepto : Las HCES son encuestas que registran compras y consumo de alimentos a nivel de hogar 9. Son esenciales para analizar patrones diet√©ticos, pero requieren limpieza para eliminar inconsistencias.

Ejemplo en R :

library(tidyverse)

# Datos simulados de HCES (consumo de alimentos en gramos)
hc_data <- tibble(
 alimento = c("Az√∫car", "Arroz", "Az√∫car morena", "Harina fortificada"),
 cantidad_g = c(500, 1200, NA, 800),
 hogar_id = c(1, 1, 2, 2)
)

# Limpieza: Estandarizar nombres y eliminar valores faltantes
hc_clean <- hc_data %>%
 mutate(alimento = case_when(
 str_detect(alimento, "Az√∫car") ~ "Az√∫car", # Unificar "Az√∫car" y "Az√∫car morena"
 TRUE ~ alimento
 )) %>%
 filter(!is.na(cantidad_g)) # Eliminar registros sin datos

Paso 2: Vinculaci√≥n con Tablas de Composici√≥n de Alimentos (FCT)

Las FCT contienen informaci√≥n nutricional de alimentos (ej: hierro, vitamina A). Al vincularlas con HCES, calculamos la ingesta de nutrientes por hogar

Ejemplo en R :

# FCT simulada (nutrientes por 100g)
fct_data <- tibble(
 alimento = c("Az√∫car", "Arroz", "Harina fortificada"),
 hierro_mg = c(0.1, 2.5, 5.0),
 vitamina_a_ug = c(0, 0, 500)
)

# Combinar HCES con FCT
hc_nutrientes <- hc_clean %>%
 left_join(fct_data, by = "alimento") %>%
 mutate(hierro_total = cantidad_g * hierro_mg / 100) # Calcular hierro total consumido

Paso 3: Evaluaci√≥n de adecuaci√≥n nutricional (EAR, RNI, UL)

Concepto : EAR (Requerimiento Promedio Estimado) : Nivel de ingesta que cubre las necesidades del 50% de la poblaci√≥n.

RNI (Requerimiento Nutricional de Ingesta) : Meta para cubrir el 97-98% de la poblaci√≥n.

UL (L√≠mite M√°ximo Seguro) : Ingesta m√°xima sin riesgo de toxicidad.

Ejemplo en R :

# EAR de hierro para mujeres (18-50 a√±os): 18 mg/d√≠a
hc_nutrientes %>%
 group_by(hogar_id) %>%
 summarise(ingesta_hierro = sum(hierro_total)) %>%
 mutate(adepto = ifelse(ingesta_hierro >= 18, "S√≠", "No"))

Visualizaci√≥n con ggstatsplot :

library(ggstatsplot)

gghistostats(
 data = hc_nutrientes,
 x = ingesta_hierro,
 title = "Ingesta de hierro vs. EAR (18 mg/d√≠a)",
 binwidth = 2
)

Paso 4: C√°lculo de consumo aparente con AME/AFE

Concepto : La FAO recomienda ajustar el consumo por tama√±o del hogar usando Equivalentes Adultos (AME/AFE) . Por ejemplo, un ni√±o <10 a√±os equivale a 0.5 AME

# Datos de hogares (miembros y edades)
hogares <- tibble(
 hogar_id = c(1, 2),
 miembros = list(
 tibble(edad = c(30, 5), genero = c("M", "F")), # Hogar 1: adulto + ni√±o
 tibble(edad = c(40, 15), genero = c("M", "M")) # Hogar 2: 2 adultos
 )
)

# Calcular AME total por hogar
hogares <- hogares %>%
 mutate(ame_total = map_dbl(miembros, ~ sum(
 ifelse(.x$edad < 10, 0.5, 1) # Ni√±os <10 = 0.5 AME
 )))

# Consumo aparente per c√°pita
hc_consumo_aparente <- hc_nutrientes %>%
 left_join(hogares, by = "hogar_id") %>%
 mutate(consumo_aparente = hierro_total / ame_total)

Paso 5: Modelado de escenarios de fortificaci√≥n

Concepto :

Simular la adici√≥n de nutrientes a alimentos (ej: hierro en harina) permite predecir impacto en la ingesta.

Ejemplo con gtsummary :

library(gtsummary)

# Escenario: Harina fortificada con +5 mg de hierro/100g
hc_fortificado <- hc_nutrientes %>%
 mutate(hierro_total = ifelse(alimento == "Harina fortificada",
 cantidad_g * (hierro_mg + 5) / 100,
 hierro_total))

# Comparaci√≥n pre-post fortificaci√≥n
tbl_summary(
 hc_nutrientes %>% select(ingesta_hierro),
 hc_fortificado %>% select(ingesta_hierro),
 label = list(ingesta_hierro ~ "Hierro (mg/d√≠a)"),
 statistic = list(ingesta_hierro ~ "{mean} ¬± {sd}")
)

Herramientas R utilizadas :

tidyverse : Manipulaci√≥n y limpieza de datos .

ggstatsplot : Visualizaci√≥n estad√≠stica r√°pida.

gtsummary : Res√∫menes tabulares para comparaciones.
